INT cm_get_error ( INT  code,
char *  string 
)

Convert error code to string. Used after cm_connect_experiment to print error string in command line programs or windows programs.

Parameters:
code Error code as defined in midas.h
string Error string
Returns:
CM_SUCCESS

INT cm_msg ( INT  message_type,
char *  filename,
INT  line,
const char *  routine,
const char *  format,
  ... 
)

This routine can be called whenever an internal error occurs or an informative message is produced. Different message types can be enabled or disabled by setting the type bits via cm_set_msg_print().

Attention:
Do not add the "\n" escape carriage control at the end of the formated line as it is already added by the client on the receiving side. 
   ...
   cm_msg(MINFO, "my program", "This is a information message only);
   cm_msg(MERROR, "my program", "This is an error message with status:%d", my_status);
   cm_msg(MTALK, "my_program", My program is Done!");
   ...
Parameters:
message_type (See midas_macro).
filename Name of source file where error occured
line Line number where error occured
routine Routine name.
format message to printout, ... Parameters like for printf()
Returns:
CM_SUCCESS

Definition at line 1233 of file midas.c.

01257       sprintf(send_message, "[%s] ", routine);
01258    else {
01259       rpc_get_name(str);
01260       if (str[0])
01261          sprintf(send_message, "[%s] ", str);
01262       else
01263          send_message[0] = 0;
01264    }
01265

01267 
01268    /* preceed error messages with file and line info */
01269    if (message_type == MT_ERROR) {
01270       sprintf(str, "[%s:%d:%s] ", pc, line, routine);
01271       strcat(send_message, str);
01272       strcat(local_message, str);
01273    }
01274 
01275    /* print argument list into message */
01276    va_start(argptr, format);
01277    vsprintf(str, (char *) format, argptr);
01278    va_end(argptr);
01279    strcat(send_message, str);
01280    strcat(local_message, str);
01281 
01282    /* call user function if set via cm_set_msg_print */
01283    if (_message_print != NULL && (message_type & _message_mask_user) != 0)
01284       _message_print(local_message);
01285 
01286    /* return if system mask is not set */
01287    if ((message_type & _message_mask_system) == 0) {
01288       in_routine = FALSE;
01289       return CM_SUCCESS;
01290    }
01291 
01292    /* copy message to event */
01293    pevent = (EVENT_HEADER *) event;
01294    strcpy(event + sizeof(EVENT_HEADER), send_message);
01295 
01296    /* send event if not of type MLOG */
01297    if (message_type != MT_LOG) {
01298       /* if no message buffer already opened, do so now */
01299       if (_msg_buffer == 0) {
01300          status = bm_open_buffer(MESSAGE_BUFFER_NAME, MESSAGE_BUFFER_SIZE, &_msg_buffer);
01301          if (status != BM_SUCCESS && status != BM_CREATED) {
01302             in_routine = FALSE;
01303             return status;
01304          }
01305       }
01306 
01307       /* setup the event header and send the message */
01308       bm_compose_event(pevent, EVENTID_MESSAGE, (WORD) message_type,
01309                        strlen(event + sizeof(EVENT_HEADER)) + 1, 0);
01310       bm_send_event(_msg_buffer, event, pevent->data_size + sizeof(EVENT_HEADER), SYNC);
01311    }
01312 
01313    /* log message */
01314    cm_msg_log(message_type, send_message);
01315 
01316    in_routine = FALSE;
01317 
01318    return CM_SUCCESS;
01319 }

char *  filename,
INT  line,
const char *  facility,
const char *  routine,
const char *  format,
  ... 
)

This routine is similar to cm_msg(). It differs from cm_msg() only by the logging destination being a file given through the argument list i.e:facility

INT cm_msg_register ( void(*)(HNDLE, HNDLE, EVENT_HEADER *, void *)  func  ) 

Register a dispatch function for receiving system messages.

  • example code from mlxspeaker.c 
    void receive_message(HNDLE hBuf, HNDLE id, EVENT_HEADER *header, void *message)
{
  char str[256], *pc, *sp;
  // print message
  printf("%s\n", (char *)(message));

  printf("evID:%x Mask:%x Serial:%i Size:%d\n"
                 ,header->event_id
                 ,header->trigger_mask
                 ,header->serial_number
                 ,header->data_size);
  pc = strchr((char *)(message),']')+2;
  ...
  // skip none talking message
  if (header->trigger_mask == MT_TALK ||
      header->trigger_mask == MT_USER)
   ...
}

int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
  ...
  // now connect to server
  status = cm_connect_experiment(host_name, exp_name, "Speaker", NULL);
  if (status != CM_SUCCESS)
    return 1;
  // Register callback for messages
  cm_msg_register(receive_message);
  ...
}

    func Dispatch function.
    Returns:

INT cm_msg_retrieve ( INT  n_message,
char *  message,
INT *  buf_size 
)

Retrieve old messages from log file

Parameters:
n_message Number of messages to retrieve
message buf_size bytes of messages, separated by
characters. The returned number of bytes is normally smaller than the initial buf_size, since only full lines are returned.
*buf_size Size of message buffer to fill
Returns:
CM_SUCCESS

01558       offset = ftell(f);
01559       if (offset != 0) {
01560          /* go to end of line */
01561          fgets(message, *buf_size - 1, f);
01562          offset = ftell(f) - offset;
01563          *buf_size -= offset;
01564       }
01565 
01566       memset(message, 0, *buf_size);
01567       fread(message, 1, *buf_size - 1, f);
01568       message[*buf_size - 1] = 0;

01570 
01571       p = message + (*buf_size - 2);
01572 
01573       /* goto end of buffer */
01574       while (p != message && *p == 0)
01575          p--;
01576 
01577       /* strip line break */
01578       while (p != message && (*p == '\n' || *p == '\r'))
01579          *(p--) = 0;
01580 
01581       /* trim buffer so that last n_messages remain */
01582       for (i = 0; i < n_message; i++) {
01583          while (p != message && *p != '\n')
01584             p--;
01585 
01586          while (p != message && (*p == '\n' || *p == '\r'))
01587             p--;
01588       }
01589       if (p != message) {
01590          p++;
01591          while (*p == '\n' || *p == '\r')
01592             p++;
01593       }
01594 
01595       *buf_size = (*buf_size - 1) - ((PTYPE) p - (PTYPE) message);
01596 
01597       memmove(message, p, *buf_size);
01598       message[*buf_size] = 0;
01599    }
01600 
01601    return CM_SUCCESS;
01602 }

INT cm_set_msg_print ( INT  system_mask,
INT  user_mask,
int(*)(const char *)  func 
)

Set message masks. When a message is generated by calling cm_msg(), it can got to two destinatinons. First a user defined callback routine and second to the "SYSMSG" buffer.

A user defined callback receives all messages which satisfy the user_mask.

int message_print(const char *msg)
{
  char str[160];

  memset(str, ' ', 159);
  str[159] = 0;
  if (msg[0] == '[')
    msg = strchr(msg, ']')+2;
  memcpy(str, msg, strlen(msg));
  ss_printf(0, 20, str);
  return 0;
}
...
  cm_set_msg_print(MT_ALL, MT_ALL, message_print);
...
Parameters:
system_mask Bit masks for MERROR, MINFO etc. to send system messages.
user_mask Bit masks for MERROR, MINFO etc. to send messages to the user callback.
func Function which receives all printout. By setting "puts", messages are just printed to the screen.
Returns:
CM_SUCCESS

Definition at line 1032 of file midas.c.

References _message_mask_system, _message_mask_user, _message_print, and BM_SUCCESS.

Referenced by cam_init_rpc(), cm_connect_experiment1(), CMExperiment::Connect(), interprete(), main(), and CMExperiment::~CMExperiment().

01033 {
01034    _message_mask_system = system_mask;
01035    _message_mask_user = user_mask;
01036    _message_print = func;
01037 
01038    return BM_SUCCESS;
01039 }
